Baumann, S. Lippert and K. Thomke Inst. fur Physikalische Chemie, Technische Universitdt Wien, Getreidemarkt 9, 1060 Vienna (Austria) (Received October 15, 1990; accepted November 15, 1990) Abstract Hydrogen-deuterium exchange reactions of the carbon chain of alcohols using Dz0pretreated MgO, La203, Sm203 and BP04 catalysts were examined. The surfaces of the catalysts were saturated with D20 and afterwards the reactions were carried out in the pulse mode. Mg0, LO03, S1n203 are catalysts with strong basic and weak acidic sites on their surfaces (E1cB-catalyst). BP04 is a catalyst with stronger acidic and weaker basic sites (E1-catalyst). Hydrogen-deuterium exchange takes place at the hydroxyl group and at the ss-position to the hydroxyl group of the alcohols when MgO, La203 and Sm203 were used. On carrying out the reaction with BP04, no deuterium uptake was detected in the chain of carbon atoms, but rather only at the hydroxyl group. The dependence of deuterium uptake on temperature was examined using gas chromatographic and mass spectrometric methods. We selected a temperature range beginning with a deuterium uptake of 1096 into the carbon chain and ending with a conversion of 596 to reaction products (such as alkenes, aldehydes or ketones by dehydration or dehydrogenation reactions) as a 'deuteration window'. The temperature limits of a window are a compromise between the loss of reactant and an appreciable deuterium uptake. The 'windows' appeared between 170 and 290 C for the alcohols used. The limits of deuterium uptake and onset of secondary reactions can be correlated with the potential curves of elimination reactions. Introduction The demand for isotopically labelled compounds in chemical science is increasing with the growing application of physical methods of analysis, but their actual use is often restricted by high prices. In chemical science deuteriumlabelled compounds play an important role in examining reaction mechanisms, for kinetic studies and, last but not least, as solvents. Our studies of heterogeneously-catalysed hydrogen-deuterium exchange reactions in the gas phase were aimed to develop a method for a cheaper production of at least some deuterium-labelled compounds. Therefore as a deuterium source we use deuterium oxide, which is known as a cheap and harmless reagent compared with DZ or other deuterated compounds. The selection of catalysts was based on the previous work of Thomke [ 1-5 ], who examined the catalytic dehydration of the a- and P-disubstituted 0304-5102/91/$3.50 0 1991- Elsevier Sequoia, Lausanne 34 ethanols R' CHOHCHZRZ (R' = H, CHs, CHZCH3; RZ - H, CH3, CHZCH3) by means of hydrogen-deuterium exchange reactions. Using BP04, deuterium was detected only in the hydroxyl group and in the formed alkenes. Using Sm203, deuterium was found in the hydroxyl group, the formed alkenes and in the carbon chain of the alcohol at ss- and j3'-positions. Using Ca3(P04)2, deuterium appeared in the hydroxyl group, but not in the carbon chain of the alcohol nor in the alkenes. The formation of alkenes by /3-elimination reactions of alcohols in homogeneous solution has been well studied and can proceed in three different ways (see Mg. 1): (1) from the alcohol OH- is first split off. In a second step, a proton is removed from the carbenium ion and an alkene is formed (E1-mechanism). (2) A proton is removed first and a carbanion is formed. In a second step OH - is split off (E 1 cB-mechanism). (3) Both the proton and the hydroxyl group are removed at nearly the same moment; there is no ionic intermediate state (E2-mechanism). E 1 and E 1cB are two-step mechanisms. The proton split-off is a reversible reaction in both cases. This means that HID-exchange in E 1 is only possible if OH- is already removed. The carbenium ion cannot revert to the alcohol, hence deuterium exchange occurs during the second step, causing deuterium uptake only into the alkene. Thornke investigated elimination reactions by the use of various deuterated 2-butanols [5]. Catalysts favoring the E1mechanism of dehydration of 2-butanol will be called 'E1-catalysts' (such as BP04, Ta20b, Mo03 and aluminosilicates [6]). Under the conditions of an E 1 cB-mechanism, H/D exchange can take place during the first step of the reaction. It is possible that the carbanion stabilizes by integration of D+, whereby a deuterated alcohol is formed. If the alcohol first exchanges more than one deuterium atom and then undergoes the dehydration reaction, deuterium can also be detected in the alkene. Catalysts supporting this reaction pathway during the catalytic dehydration of 2-butanol will be called 'E 1 cB-catalysts' (such as La2O3, Sm203, Th02 or alkaline earth oxides [5, 6]). If both proton and OH- are removed simultaneously, an E2-mechanism can be invoked. There is no possibility for H/D exchange, and deuterium is -XO -; - - -H E 1 E2 H_HX / O -e-e- E Ic8 0 Fig. 1. [5, 61). It should be pointed out that the mechanism of a dehydration reaction depends on the reactants, catalysts and temperature. Moreover, it is impossible to determine pure mechanisms based on product distribution. But we can consider an E 1 cB mechanism coupled with a small amount of E 1, for example. Halasz et al. [61 have described the mechanisms by their potential curves (see Fig. 2). By investigating /3-elimination reactions using different catalysts, conclusions can be drawn about the strength of the active sites on the surface of catalysts. Dehydration of alcohols depends upon the (relative) strength of EPA-(electron-poor-) and EPD-(electron-rich-) sites on the surface [6, 7]. (1) If acidic sites (EPA) are very strong compared with the basic sites on the surface, it is easy to abstract OH- from the alcohol, causing carbenium ion formation (El mechanism). (2) On the contrary, if acidic sites are very weak in relation to basic ones, proton abstraction will proceed quite easily by formation of a carbanion (E 1 cB mechanism). (3) Finally, if acidic and basic sites are of equal strength, the proton and the hydroxyl group will be removed simultaneously (E2 mechanism). Alcohols interact with the surface via ss-protons and hydroxyl groups [ 7 ] (see Fig. 3). For the synthesis of deuterated alcohols, E 1 cB catalysts seemed to be the best choice. In the literature they are also described as solid bases [8I, for example Laz03, Sm203, Mg0, CaO, SrO, BaO, Zr203, Th02 or Ce02. As a representative E1 catalyst we used BP04. Experimental A simple microcatalytic pulse reactor can be constructed by replacing the glass liner of a GC split/splitless injection port for capillary columns by a silica tubing containing a sintered quaitz plug as a catalyst support. By variation of temperature and preliminary pressure, reaction conditions can be changed easily. The GC was connected with a Finnigan MAT ion trap 3$ detector ITD 700. As separation column we used a Durabond Wax fused silica capillary column 30 m x 0.32 mm, film thickness 50 nm, from J&W Scientific. Reactants: As deuterium source D20 99.990 from Merck was used. All reactants and catalysts used were of the highest available purity. Boron phosphate BP04 (EGA-Chemie, SteinheimlAlbuch) was calcined 10 h at 500 C (BET surface: 7.4 m2 g- 1). Magnesium oxide was prepared by 10 h decarboxylation of MgC03 at 10$0 C (1 ]. As BET surface 14.9 m2 g-' was measured. After the decarboxylation no more MgC03 was detectable in the formed MgO by X-ray diffraction. After treating the MgO with 3 pulses of D20, it was totally transformed into Mg(OD)2. Thus, the active catalyst for deuteration is not MgO but its deutero-oxide! Lanthanum oxide La203 (Merck p.A.) was calcined 2 h at 500 C, placed in the reactor and flushed with carrier gas (He 5.0). The analysis of D20treated La2O3 indicated a conversion to La(OD)3. No hexagonal La2O3 was detectable. It is possible that the catalyst contained small amounts of La202CO3 (BET surface: 7.3 m2 g- I). Samarium oxide SM203 (Research Chemicals, 99.99'0) was prepared in a similar manner. X-ray diffraction indicated a high amount of Sm(OD)3. Only a small amount of cubic T1203-like SM203 and small amounts of basic samarium carbonate were detected (BET surface: 7.2 m2 g- 1). At lower temperatures the catalysts also contained adsorbed D20, because when the weight increase after D20 treatment was measured, the oxides had taken up more than the equivalent amount of D20. Specific surfaces of catalysts were measured by an areameter (Strohiein) X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out with a Phillips powder diffractometer PW 1710. After calcination (30 min at 300 C) the reactions were carried out in the pulse mode. The catalysts were treated with two to four pulses of deuterium oxide followed by one pulse of the reactant (one pulse = 1 ,ul). Calculation of deuterium content in products A common method to determine the deuterium content of a pure substance (pure in the chemical sense, not in the sense of containing isotopes) is to measure the height ratio of the molecule peaks (M;+) in the mass chromatogram. Mass chromatograms of compounds including oxygen often show a significant peak at M+ + 1 caused by chemical ionisation (oxonium ion formation by H+ addition). This can be interpreted as a higher deuterium content. We gauged the system by injection of different volumes of undeuterated reactant. Thus we could correct the mass chromatograms of deuterated compounds by subtracting the peaks due to chemical ionisation. 37 The percentage of molecules including i deuterium atoms can be calculated by eqn. Discussion It was shown that alcohols undergo the exchange reaction at ss- and 3'-positions when MgO, SM203 and La203 (E 1 cB catalysts) were used. Moreover, the proton of the hydroxyl group was also exchanged. Methanol does not contain ss-protons, therefore we could not find deuterium at the carbon atom. BP04 did not catalyse any deuterium uptake into the carbon chain of alcohols. BP04 (El catalyst) influences the alcohols such that hydroxyl abstraction proceeds first. It is not possible to stop the reaction at a certain temperature to obtain deuterated reactants, because the energy level of the molecules is high enough to form alkenes. With increasing temperature the deuterium uptake goes through a maximum. The lower deuterium content at high temperatures is caused by the lower D20 content of the catalyst at the upper limit of the deuteration windows. The deuteration windows described above can be compared with the principal path an E 1 cB reaction follows. The first step (removal of a proton) is possible at relatively low temperatures because the activation energy for this process is low compared with the activation energy for the abstraction of the hydroxyl group. The low activation energy for H+ abstraction is on the other hand caused by strong interactions with the basic sites (EPD) of the surface. Thus we can consider that the lower temperature limit of the deuteration window can be compared with the first step of the potential curve of the E1cB reaction (H+ split off). At higher temperature ranges 43 (upper limit of the window), most of the molecules also have enough energy to undergo the second step of the reaction (OH- split off). Oxidic. catalysts (MgO, SM203 and La203) were totally transformed to their deutero-oxides by D20 treatment. We consider that the catalysts also contained a certain amount of adsorbed D20.
